document.title: "Hospital at home" care shows similar mortality and subsequent hospital admissions to hospital care for older patients with acutely decompensated chronic heart failure
document.body: <![CDATA[ Heart failure remains one of the most common reasons for emergency hospital admission, and readmission rates are high when post-discharge follow-up is poor or in frequent. There is good evidence that multidisciplinary programmes are effective at reducing the risk of readmission to hospital for patients recently discharged after treatment of acute decompensation, particularly where these programmes include frequent contact with the patient at home, either physically or by telephone1 or by remotely monitoring physiological data.2 Much less attention has been directed to avoiding hospital admission altogether for those experiencing the crisis of acute decompensation by providing greatly increased clinical support at home-the “hospital at home” concept.]]>

document.title: 22 October 2009 - Sleep deprivation and memory
document.body:
“The forgetfulness brought on by insomnia may be countered with drugs,” says a report on BBC News today.

Research in mice looked at a chemical pathway in the part of the brain that deals with memory. It showed that sleep deprivation increases levels of an enzyme called PDE4 and reduces levels of a molecule called cAMP. The researchers were able to manipulate these pathways with a drug called Rolipram, which improved some of the memory problems of the sleep-deprived mice.

]]>

document.title: 28 May 2009 - Glowing monkeys 'milestone'
document.description: Behind the Headlines - your guide to the science the makes the news.
document.body:
“The world's first ‘glow in the dark’ monkeys could help in cure for diseases such as Parkinson's,” The Daily Telegraph has reported.

The news comes from Japanese research into genetically modifying marmosets, a type of monkey that breeds rapidly. Monkey embryos were injected with a jellyfish gene that makes animals glow green under ultra-violet light, allowing scientists to tell easily whether the foreign gene successfully combined with the monkey DNA. A number of these embryos grew into monkeys that glowed under UV light, and these, in turn, were bred with regular monkeys. These offspring also carried the fluorescent gene. Theoretically, scientists could create and breed monkeys with genes for incurable human illnesses such as Parkinson’s disease. These monkeys could then be used in experiments as animal models of human disease.

]]>

document.title: A Double-Blind, Delayed-Start Trial of Rasagiline in Parkinson's Disease
document.body:
Background:
A therapy that slows disease progression is the major unmet need in Parkinson's disease.

Methods:
In this double-blind trial, we examined the possibility that rasagiline has disease-modifying effects in Parkinson's disease. A total of 1176 subjects with untreated Parkinson's disease were randomly assigned to receive rasagiline (at a dose of either 1 mg or 2 mg per day) for 72 weeks (the early-start group) or placebo for 36 weeks followed by rasagiline (at a dose of either 1 mg or 2 mg per day) for 36 weeks (the delayed-start group). To determine a positive result with either dose, the early-start treatment group had to meet each of three hierarchical end points of the primary analysis based on the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS, a 176-point scale, with higher numbers indicating more severe disease): superiority to placebo in the rate of change in the UPDRS score between weeks 12 and 36, superiority to delayed-start treatment in the change in the score between baseline and week 72, and noninferiority to delayed-start treatment in the rate of change in the score between weeks 48 and 72.

Results:
Early-start treatment with rasagiline at a dose of 1 mg per day met all end points in the primary analysis: a smaller mean (±SE) increase (rate of worsening) in the UPDRS score between weeks 12 and 36 (0.09±0.02 points per week in the early-start group vs. 0.14±0.01 points per week in the placebo group, P=0.01), less worsening in the score between baseline and week 72 (2.82±0.53 points in the early-start group vs. 4.52±0.56 points in the delayed-start group, P=0.02), and noninferiority between the two groups with respect to the rate of change in the UPDRS score between weeks 48 and 72 (0.085±0.02 points per week in the early-start group vs. 0.085±0.02 points per week in the delayed-start group, P<0.001). All three end points were not met with rasagiline at a dose of 2 mg per day, since the change in the UPDRS score between baseline and week 72 was not significantly different in the two groups (3.47±0.50 points in the early-start group and 3.11±0.50 points in the delayed-start group, P=0.60).

Conclusions:
Early treatment with rasagiline at a dose of 1 mg per day provided benefits that were consistent with a possible disease-modifying effect, but early treatment with rasagiline at a dose of 2 mg per day did not. Because the two doses were associated with different outcomes, the study results must be interpreted with caution. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00256204 [ClinicalTrials.gov] .)

]]>

document.description: This report suggests that older people get a poor deal when finding a care home.
document.body:
This report suggests that older people get a poor deal when finding a care home. Whilst care homes are improving the information they give to prospective residents, advertised fees for places in the same care home can vary hugely, sometimes from £650 to £1,500 a week, without a clear explanation of why some people pay more than others and what their money will buy. The report also showed that sometimes people paying for their own care can subsidise those people paid for by the local council, where councils negotiate lower rates.

 

]]>

The objective of this study, designed as a randomized controlled trial, was to decrease the length-of-stay (LOS) of hospitalized patients on a waiting list for admission to an inpatient geriatric assessment unit (GAU), and to optimize use of the GAU and other hospital services.  

Conclusions:

We conclude that for Canadian hospitals in which extensive stays of frail elderly patients, "bed blockage", and thus access to unit-based geriatric services are common problems, the GAIT can efficiently decrease hospital LOS, increase home placement, and may improve outcomes.

document.title: A New Strategy for Carers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ LATER LIFE,SCREENING AND SURVEILLANCE,SURVEILLANCE,SECONDARY CARE,HEALTH & WELLBEING]]>
document.description: Counsel and Care's latest policy discussion paper on carers of older people.
document.body:
Better support and recognition of carers of older people, particularly older carers, are crucial to proposed reform of social care, says Counsel and Care, the national charity getting the best care and support for older people, their families and carers, in its latest policy paper published today (30 October 2007). There are currently 1.5 million people over 60 providing unpaid care and 8,000 carers are aged 90 or over. 

 

A New Strategy for Carers: better support for families and carers of older people, sets out recommendations for the Prime Minister’s review of the 1999 strategy for carers.  Critical to better supporting carers are radical improvements in social care services which will also be the subject of a green paper next year.

 

Included in Counsel and Care’s discussion paper’s recommendations are that government:

 

  • addresses the needs of different types of carers, and recognises their diversity 
  • reform the benefits system that currently penalises those carers who want to work, and further punishes them when they reach pensionable age by removing Carer’s Allowance
  • increase carer’s premium for Income Support/Pension Credit, alongside an increase in Carer’s Allowance
  • treat carers as equal stakeholders in the health and social care partnership
  • make it easier for carers to work by better promoting the right to request flexible working and extending tax exemptions to care vouchers

 

Referring to the recent report published by Carers UK showing that carers save the country £87 billion per year – more than the annual spend on the NHS  - Counsel and Care has supported Carers UK and other campaigners in demanding that carers are included as equals in the delivery of health and social care services.  Recent research from the University of Leeds for Carers UK has shown that: 

 

  • 41% of ‘new’ carers are caring for someone who does not receive any other services
  • 34% of ‘longer term’ carers struggle to make ends meet financially
  • between 40% and 50% of working carers felt that there was little flexibility and sensitivity in service delivery, which hampered their efforts to get support. 

 

]]>

document.title: A randomized trial of office-based screening for common problems in older persons
document.body: <![CDATA[ PURPOSE: To test the effectiveness of a 10-minute office-staff administered screen to evaluate malnutrition/weight loss, visual impairment, hearing loss, cognitive impairment, urinary incontinence, depression, physical limitations, and reduced leg mobility among older persons seen in office practice. This screen was coupled with clinical summaries to assist the physician in further evaluating and managing the screen-included problems. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Twenty-six community-based office practices of internists and family physicians in Los Angeles were randomized to intervention or control groups. Two hundred and sixty-one patients aged > or = 70 years and seeing these physicians for a new visit or a physical examination participated in the study. At the enrollment visit intervention group patients were administered the screening measure and their physicians were given the pertinent clinical summaries. Outcome measures were detection of, and intervention for conditions screened, and health status 6 months after the intervention. RESULTS: Hearing loss was both more commonly detected (40% intervention versus 28% control) and further evaluated (29% versus 16%) by physicians in the intervention group (P < 0.05). No other differences in the frequency of problem detection or intervention were noted between groups. Six months after the intervention no differences were noted in health status between groups. CONCLUSIONS: A brief measure to screen for common conditions in older persons was associated with more frequent detection and follow-up assessment of hearing loss. Although the measure was well accepted by physicians and their staffs, it did not appear to affect detection and intervention in regard to the other screen-included conditions, or health status at 6 months.]]>

document.title: A reassessment of risks and benefits of dopamine agonists in Parkinson's disease
document.body: <![CDATA[ Neurologists have several choices of drugs that have been shown to be effective for the treatment of the symptoms of Parkinson's disease. Among the first options are the dopamine agonists, which are commonly used both as an early monotherapy and as an adjunct therapy to levodopa. However, before starting any treatment, the overall benefit-to-risk ratio to individual patients must be considered. For the dopamine agonists, the available evidence on their symptomatic efficacy, effect on long-term levodopa-related motor complications, putative effect on progression of disease, and adverse event profile must be taken into account. Recently, the ocurrence of adverse events such as leg oedema, daytime somnolence, impulse control disorders, and fibrosis have increasingly been recognised. The risks of these potentially serious adverse events must therefore be taken into account and treatment decisions should be based on considerations of risks versus benefits for individual patients.]]>

document.body:
Design:
randomised controlled trial. ISRCTN26474556 [controlled-trials.com] .

Blinding:
blinded (outcome assessors).

Setting:
primary care practices in the northwestern Netherlands.

Patients:
170 general practice patients >=75 years of age (mean age 81 y, 74% women) who had Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) scores >=16 and did not meet DSM-IV criteria for depressive or anxiety disorder in the previous 12 months as measured by the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI). Patients with serious cognitive decline were excluded. All patients completed 3 months of watchful waiting, after which they completed a second CES-D questionnaire. Patients with scores >=16 underwent a diagnostic MINI. Patients with CES-D scores >=16 but who did not have a depressive or anxiety disorder were randomized.

document.title: Age Related Macular Degeneration Annual Evidence Update 2009
document.body: <![CDATA[ This AEU is an update to the 2008 update and 2007 National Knowledge Week and so the same scope has been followed.   The term age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is used to cover both wet and dry forms of AMD.  The dry form of the condition is also known as geographic atrophy and the wet form of the condition is also known as neovascular AMD.  Whilst an overview on early disease (which may not be visually impairing) is important to include for the epidemiology of this condition, the emphasis of this AEU is on sight-threatening or visually impairing forms.   The developments in therapeutic and surgical interventions available for AMD that are featured in this update relate to the wet form of AMD.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Later Life]]>
document.title: Ageing Assets: Implications of population ageing for the South East region
document.description: A report prepared by Population Ageing Associates for the Social Inclusion Partnership South East (SIPSE) Older People Action Group - October 2005.
document.body:
111-1Ageing Assets: Implications of population ageing for the South East region

This report has been commissioned by the Older People’s Action Group of the Social Inclusion Partnership South East. The aim is to inform regional and local planning by setting out key information and projections relating to the older population of the region over the  coming years. The report discusses the implications of ageing in the South East region and considers in particular the opportunities for action at regional level by regional organisations.


 

It is well-known that the population of Britain is ageing. The South East region is no exception. People are living longer. The baby boom generation is getting older. And fertility is low – families are not  having enough children to reproduce themselves. The population of the region is growing faster than the UK average. An increase of around 12% is projected over the next 25 years, taking the population from 8.1 to 9.2 million. Most of the projected population growth is expected to be in the over 60 age group. Half the adult population are projected to be over the age of 50 by the early 2020s, which means that at that time half the voters are likely to be concerned with the matters discussed in this report.


 

This report addresses the issues arising from population ageing that are most relevant to the regional planning processes. The overall aim, it is suggested, should be to ensure that contributions and needs of both present and future generations of older people are consciously taken into account in the planning process. By thinking inclusively, future social exclusion will be minimised.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Later Life]]>
document.title: Ageing populations: the challenges ahead
document.body: <![CDATA[ If the pace of increase in life expectancy in developed countries over the past two centuries continues through the 21st century, most babies born since 2000 in France, Germany, Italy, the UK, the USA, Canada, Japan, and other countries with long life expectancies will celebrate their 100th birthdays. Although trends differ between countries, populations of nearly all such countries are ageing as a result of low fertility, low immigration, and long lives. A key question is: are increases in life expectancy accompanied by a concurrent postponement of functional limitations and disability? The answer is still open, but research suggests that ageing processes are modifiable and that people are living longer without severe disability. This finding, together with technological and medical development and redistribution of work, will be important for our chances to meet the challenges of ageing populations.]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ NEUROLOGICAL CONDITIONS,DEMENTIA,MENTAL HEALTH,LATER LIFE,ADULT CONDITIONS,DEMENTIA,PATHOLOGY,DEFINITION AND TYPES,CAUSES AND PREVENTION,TREATMENT AND CARE,DEMENTIA,DIAGNOSIS,CONDITIONS]]>
document.description: Up to 105,000 people with dementia are given the drugs inappropriately, according to expert predictions in the new All-Party Parliamentary Group (APPG) on Dementia report, 'Always A Last Resort', published by the Alzheimer's Society.
document.body:
An influential group of MPs is calling on the Government to stop the dangerous over-prescribing of antipsychotic drugs to people with dementia.

Up to 105,000 people with dementia are given the drugs inappropriately, according to expert predictions in the new All-Party Parliamentary Group (APPG) on Dementia report, 'Always A Last Resort'.

Antipsychotics continue to be a first resort for dealing with challenging behaviour in people with dementia, such as aggression or agitation, despite causing devastating side effects, doubling risk of death and costing the UK over £60 million a year.

'Always a Last Resort' identifies five vital steps to reduce antipsychotic use and reveals there is currently no audit or regulation of the issue. It urges the Government to use its new National Dementia Strategy to address the problem and the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence to conduct a thorough review.

]]>

1112Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: 1. Diagnosis and Screening

 

 

Link to 2008 Contents page

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

A summary of the recent evidence by Dr Amitava Banerjee.

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) is aimed at clinicians in primary care or general medicine.  It covers the following topics:

  • Definitions
  • Diagnosis
  • Diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer's Disease, Frontotemporal dementia, Lewy Body dementia, Vascular dementia
  • Further investigations
  • Screening
  • References

Definitions

There is heterogeneity in the literature in how dementia and Alzheimer's Disease are characterised in patient populations. We recommend that clinicians review both topics as ruling one out may exclude important evidence. 

Dementia

Dementia affects 17–25 million people worldwide, with an estimated four million in the US and an estimated 800,000 people in the UK. The majority of research and guidelines in the field of dementia has concerned Alzheimer’s disease (AD), which accounts for about 50% of dementia. However, the other subtypes of dementia also make up a significant disease burden.

The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV) states, "The essential feature of dementia is impairment in short-and long-term memory, associated with impairment in abstract thinking, impaired judgment, other disturbances of higher cortical function, or personality change. The disturbance is severe enough to interfere significantly with work or usual social activities or relationships with others. The diagnosis of dementia is not made if these symptoms occur ... in delirium." (DSM-IV, Feldman 2008, Chertkow 2008).

Delirium

Delirium is a syndrome characterised by the rapid onset of variable and fluctuating changes in mental status caused by physiologic consequences of a medical disturbance. DSM-IV states, "The essential feature of a delirium is a disturbance in consciousness that is accompanied by a change in cognition that cannot be better accounted for by a pre-existing or evolving dementia." (DSM-IV).

Mild cognitive impairment

The grey zone between normality and dementia is characterised as "mild cognitive impairment” (MCI). The initial criteria for mild cognitive impairment require a subjective report of cognitive decline from a former level, gradual in onset, and present for at least 6 months. “If the memory loss is severe and accompanied by significant functional impairment and other cognitive impairments, the patient meets the clinical criteria for dementia, not mild cognitive impairment” (Chertkow 2008).

Diagnosis

The diagnosis of dementia is based on history, family interview, physical examination and brief cognitive testing. A number of core laboratory tests are also recommended. Structural neuro-imaging is advised in selected cases. Other diagnostic approaches are not yet recommended for routine use in diagnosis of dementia. 

Patient history

Focus on:

  • the onset and course of the illness (gradual and insidious in Alzheimer disease, stepwise in vascular dementia)
  • past vascular history and risk factors
  • alcohol abuse
  • renal failure
  • previous head trauma.

Family interview

Focus on:

  • Personality
  • Behaviour
  • Functional impairment
  • Family support systems and the social setting.

Physical examination

Focus on potential signs of stroke.

Brief cognitive tests

Brief cognitive tests serve to determine the presence and overall severity of memory and cognitive deficits. Brief cognitive tests have a lower sensitivity and specificity than does a full neuropsychological evaluation, but they are far faster and more accessible than specialised testing.

The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is the most widely used instrument. Patients with mild dementia usually have a score of 18–26 out of 30, those with moderate dementia a score of 10–18, and those with severe dementia a score of less than 10.

A number of newer tests have been developed to provide improved sensitivity, e.g. the Montréal Cognitive Assessment, DemTect, the 7-Minute Screen, the General Practitioner Assessment of Cognition and the Behavioural Neurology Assessment short form.

All of these tests have been shown to be more accurate than the MMSE in discriminating between dementia and normal cognition, particularly in mild dementia. No brief cognitive test can differentiate between subtypes of dementia (Feldman 2008).

At this point in the evaluation, the physician has accumulated sufficient information to decide whether the patient meets clinical criteria for dementia. On the basis of consensus clinical criteria, the specific type of dementia can be determined.

Diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer’s disease

  • Dementia
  • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive functions
  • No disturbance of consciousness
  • Absence of systemic disorders or other brain diseases that could account for the progressive cognitive decline
  • Supportive features include:
      -Altered behavioural patterns
      -Family history of similar disorders, particularly if confirmed neuropathologically
  • Features that make a diagnosis of Alzeimer’s disease unlikely include:
      - Sudden onset
      -Focal neurological findings, including hemiparesis, sensory loss, visual field deficits, incoordination
      -Early presence of a gait disorder or seizure.

Frontotemporal dementia

  • Younger age of onset than AD
  • Prominent behavioural changes (e.g. social conduct dysregulation, disinhibition, perseveration, emotional blunting) OR
  • Prominent language impairment (e.g. progressive nonfluent aphasia or semantic problems, with  breakdown of word meaning and knowledge).

Dementia associated with Lewy bodies or with Parkinson disease

  • Clinical features of these 2 conditions overlap considerably
  • Dementia associated with Parkinson disease begins with idiopathic Parkinson disease for =1 year before onset of dementia, whereas Lew body dementia begins with cognitive and behavioural disorder that can have concurrent parkinsonian features
  • Neuropsychiatric features including visual hallucinations and fluctuations in disease course.

Vascular dementia

  • Typically stepwise progression
  • Hallmark cognitive feature of a dysexecutive syndrome
  • Focal neurological findings often found early in the disease course.

Further investigations

The purpose of laboratory investigations and structural neuro-imaging is to exclude a treatable disorder presenting as memory loss, e.g. renal failure, brain tumour, normal pressure hydrocephalus and subdural hemorrhages, which account for less than 1% of dementia cases.

All patients should have tests for full blood count, thyroid stimulating hormone, serum calcium, electrolytes, vitamin B12 and fasting glucose. Selective testing of serum and folate levels, syphilis screening, and HIV antibodies is recommended.

The selective use of either CT or MRI is recommended, but there is currently insufficient evidence to recommend use of functional neuro-imaging, such as PET scanning in the routine evaluation of dementia (Feldman 2008).

Neuropsychological testing provides detailed, standardized assessment across a wide range of cognitive domains, and is particularly helpful in MCI and mild dementia, but it is much more time-consuming and much more expensive than brief cognitive tests (Feldman 2008, Laws 2007, Hutchinson 2007).

There is no ideal biomarker for dementia that is currently available. The leading candidates include cerebrospinal fluid levels of ß-amyloid1–42, total tau, and phospho-tau (p-tau) proteins, but these are currently the domain of specialist research institutions and not in routine clinical practice (Diniz 2008, Petzold 2007).

Screening

Although there is currently insufficient data to suggest population-wide genetic screening for dementia, a strong family history of dementia should trigger further investigation and referral to a specialist for consultation.

A recent review recommended that clinicians should select one primary tool for dementia screening based on (1) the population receiving care; (2) an awareness of the effects of educational level, race, and age on scoring; and (3) consideration of adding 1 or 2 other tools for special situations as needed (Holsinger 2007). Such tools should take into account both cognitive and functional capacity (e.g. IADL-instrumental activities of daily living) (Castilla-Rilo 2007).

Certain dementia screening tools are available of self-administration (e.g. the Concord Informant Dementia Scale (CIDS) and the Informant Questionnaire on Cognitive Decline in the Elderly (IQCODE), but they have not yet been validated for use.

1112Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Risk factors and aetiology

 

 

Link to 2008 Contents page

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

Summary of the evidence by Dr Amitava Banerjee.

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) is aimed at clinicians in primary care or general medicine.  It covers the following topics:

  • Smoking
  • Obesity
  • Vascular and lifestyle factors
  • ApoE and Genetics of Alzheimer's Disease
  • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT)
  • Occupational exposure
  • Mild cognitive impairment

Smoking

Current smokers have a 40-80% greater risk of dementia and cognitive decline compared to never smokers (Anstey 2007), and this risk is particularly manifest among older adults. In a systematic review, former smokers were at significantly lower risk of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and yearly cognitive decline than current smokers, but there was no difference in risk of vascular dementia and any dementia between the current and former smokers (Anstey 2007).

The associations between smoking and dementia may be explained by associations between lifestyle factors (e.g. nutrition, alcohol intake and physical activity) and dementia, via effects on cardiovascular disease or its intermediate risk factors or interactions with genetic factors (e.g. apolipoprotein E genotype, ApoE).

Obesity

A meta-analysis showed a significant U-shaped association between BMI (body mass index) and dementia (P = 0.034), with dementia risk increased for obesity (OR 1.42) and underweight (OR 1.36), but not for overweight (OR 0.88) (Beydoun 2008). The association between obesity and dementia remained for both incident AD and vascular dementia (ORs of 1.80 and 1.73 respectively).

Vascular and lifestyle factors

The roles of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia in the development of dementia are not clear. Although systolic hypertension and hyperlipidaemia have been associated with increased risk of both AD and all-cause dementia, randomized trials have failed to show consistent benefit in the treatment of blood pressure or cholesterol on future risk of dementia (Patterson 2008).

Both total dietary fat intake and reduced levels of omega 3 fatty acids are associated with increased risk of dementia and a Mediterranean-style diet and fish consumption may be associated with decreased risk of AD (Patterson 2008).

A recent systematic review found that the validity of previous associations between low blood concentrations of vitamins B6 and B12, and folate and increased risk of dementia was poor due to significant heterogeneity of existing studies (Raman 2007). Without randomized controlled trial evidence, the role of diet in primary prevention of dementia is still unclear.

“Brain reserve” refers to the ability to tolerate age-related changes and disease related pathology in the brain without developing clear clinical symptoms or signs (Fratiglioni 2007). High education, adult-life occupational work complexity, as well as a mentally and socially integrated lifestyle in late life could postpone the onset of clinical dementia and AD.

Increased levels of physical activity have been linked to a reduced risk of subsequent dementia (relative risk, RR=0.50) in the Canadian Study of Health and Ageing (Patterson 2008). Daily mental activities and cognitive training have been shown to reduce the risk of all-cause dementia, and may delay cognitive decline.

Activities with physical, mental and social components probably have the most benefit.

A moderate consumption of wine (1 glass per day), compared with an intake of more or less than this amount, is associated with a reduced risk of subsequent all-cause dementia (RR 0.56) and of  AD(RR 0.53), but advice about alcohol consumption should be tempered by the known risks of excessive use in other organ systems (Patterson 2008).

There is no association between the severity of AD and the prevalence of depression, so prevention and intervention strategies for comorbid depression in AD should be aimed at all patients irrespective their disease severity (Verkaik 2007).

The role of head injury in subsequent development of dementia is unclear.

ApoE and genetics of Alzheimer's Disease (AD)

Early-onset AD is generally defined as occurring before 60 years of age and accounts for only 6%–7% of all cases of AD. To date, all 3 causative gene mutations (amyloid precursor protein gene, located on chromosome 21; presenilin-1, located on chromosome 14; and presenilin-2, located on chromosome 1) lead to the early-onset form, with autosomal dominant inheritance. 

Several genes have been implicated as risk factors in late-onset AD. Currently, only ApoE has been confirmed as a genetic risk factor in multiple large, population-based studies, particularly the association with the e4 allele. This association is stronger in women than in men, and is stronger below the age of 65 years, probably due to increasing risk of AD with age, whether or not the e4 allele is present. A recent review showed that structural brain change is associated with the ApoE genotype and that this is more prominent below the age of 65 years (Cherbuin 2007).

The sortilin-related receptor gene (SORL1) has been associated with late-onset Alzheimer's disease in several populations of different ethnic backgrounds in the United States. SORL1 is also involved in amyloid precursor protein processing, further supporting the role of the amyloid cascade in the pathogenesis of AD.

A recent meta-analysis concluded that “the impact on AD risk of genetic variants of these genes involved in Aß production, aggregation or degradation is rather limited; and therefore, attention should be given to meta-analysis of other different genes involved in these metabolic pathways” (Llorca 2008).

Although there is currently insufficient data to suggest screening for dementia, a strong family history of dementia should trigger further investigation and referral to a specialist for consultation.

Genetic testing has no significant impact on psychological outcomes, little effect on behaviour, and does not change perceived risk, and so may well be used to identify patients at risk for functional decline in the future.

HRT

Neither oestrogen-alone nor combined hormone replacement (HRT) prevent cognitive decline in older postmenopausal women when given as short term or longer term (up to 5 years) therapy (Lethaby 2008).

Occupational exposure

Although meta-analyses have implicated aluminium toxicity, pesticides and extremely low frequency electromagnetic frequency radiation (ELF-EMF) in dementia, there is insufficient data to suggest a role in causation for any of these agents (Ferreira 2008, Garcia 2008, Santibanez 2007).

Mild cognitive impairment

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) represents a condition with multiple sources of heterogeneity, including clinical presentation, aetiology and prognosis, and may represent a “predementia” state. More research is required in order to develop more reliable methods to determine its progression or improvement. A systematic review found no benefit from cholinesterase inhibitors (ChEIs) in MCI in the delay of the onset of AD or dementia (Raschetti 2007, Mariani 2007).

1112Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Pharmacological treatments

 

 

 

Link to 2008 Contents page

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

Summary of the evidence by Dr Amitava Banerjee

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) is aimed at clinicians in primary care or general medicine. It covers:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors (ChEIs)
  • Memantine
  • Other therapies
  • Treatment of neuropsychiatric and behavioural symptoms

Pharmacological treatments: Dementia

At present, there is no cure for dementia, regardless of aetiology. Current pharmacological interventions attempt to delay progression of the syndrome and improve its symptoms.

Several consensus guidelines have been produced to guide drug therapy in Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias (Qaseem 2008, Waldemar 2007, NICE 2007). A recent statement by the International Psychogeriatric Association recommended clear, pre-defined diagnostic and severity criteria and outcome measures, which include functional and executive capacity, in treatment trials for dementia.

In the context of ageing populations and demographic transition worldwide, it also emphasised the need for new cost-effectiveness analyses which take into account up-to-date, country-specific data using relevant outcome measures (Katona 2007).

American College of Physicians and the American Academy of Family Physicians Recommendations (Qaseem 2008)

  1. Clinicians should base the decision to initiate a trial of therapy with a cholinesterase inhibitor or memantine on individualized assessment. (Grade: weak recommendation, moderate-quality evidence.)
  2. Clinicians should base the choice of pharmacologic agents on tolerability, adverse effect profile, ease of use, and cost of medication. The evidence is insufficient to compare the effectiveness of different pharmacologic agents for the treatment of dementia. (Grade: weak recommendation, low-quality evidence.)
  3. There is an urgent need for further research on the clinical effectiveness of pharmacologic management of dementia (particularly combination therapy).

There is an important distinction between the statistical significance of changes in scale scores reported in trials and the clinically important improvement which patients with dementia, caregivers, and clinicians are more concerned with. As an example, for the mini-mental state examination (MMSE), a change of 3 points or more is considered clinically important (Qaseem 2008).

Cholinesterase inhibitors (ChEIs)

The most commonly used cholinesterase inhibitors (ChEIs) are donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine and tacrine. Most studies have found statistically significant improvements on global assessments, but the clinical importance of these changes is uncertain, and none of the trials have studied the long-term effects of ChEIs (Qaseem 2008, Waldemar 2007, Landmark 2008).

Adjusted indirect comparison of placebo-controlled data did not find statistically significant differences among drugs with regard to cognition, but found the relative risk of global response to be better with donepezil and rivastigmine compared with galantamine (relative risk = 1.63 and 1.42, respectively) (Hansen 2008).

The evidence for clinical benefit is weakest for tacrine, which also has serious side effects, including liver damage. The incidence of adverse events was generally lowest for donepezil and highest for rivastigmine.

In one study, Huperzine A (a new ChEI) had some beneficial effects on general cognitive function, global clinical status, behavioral disturbance and functional performance, with no obvious serious adverse events for patients with AD, but there is inadequate evidence to make any recommendation about its use (Li 2008).

The use of ChEIs in mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has not been associated with any delay in the onset of AD or dementia (Raschetti 2007).

Memantine

Memantine is an non-competitive NMDA receptor antagonist which has been shown to give statistically significant, but not clinically important, improvement in cognition scores for moderate to severe Alzheimer disease, as well as all levels of severity for Alzheimer disease and vascular dementia, comparable to existing ChEIs (Smith Doody 2007, Qaseem 2008).

Other therapies

AD may be caused by the formation of extracellular senile beta-amyloid (Aß) plaques. In vitro and mouse model studies have demonstrated that metal protein attenuating compounds (MPACs) promote the solubilisation and clearance of Aß. A recent Cochrane review found that there is currently no evidence to recommend use of clioquinol (PBT1), which is a MPAC (Sampson 2008).

Although hyperlipidaemia has been associated with increased risk of both AD and all-cause dementia, statin use did not show a beneficial effect on the risk of dementia or Alzheimer's disease (Zhou 2007).

A systematic review of the use of SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) showed no evidence to support positive outcomes in dementia, but this was largely due to omissions in clinical trial design, as opposed to reporting of negative outcomes (Chow 2007).

There is no evidence of an effect of vitamin B6 or B12 or folic acid supplementation, alone or in combination, on cognitive function testing in people with either normal or impaired cognitive function (Balk 2007).

Neuropsychiatric and behavioural symptoms

Although there have been numerous well-designed studies of the pharmacotherapy of neuropsychiatric symptoms in AD, safer and more effective treatments are urgently needed (Herrmann 2007).

The atypical antipsychotics (risperidone and olanzapine) are more effective than placebo in the setting of severe agitation, aggression, and psychosis, but this is counterbalanced by safety concerns that including risk of stroke and death.

ChEIs and memantine have modest benefits for patients with mildly to moderately severe symptoms.

Although antidepressants are effective for treating depression in AD, the efficacy of trazodone and citalopram in treatment of agitation and aggression is unknown. Carbamazepine is effective but its side effect profile and drug interactions limit its use. Benzodiazepines should only be used for short-term, as-needed use. There are inadequate data on other pharmacologic interventions, such as beta blockers, valproate, buspirone, and oestrogen preparations (Herrmann 2007).

1112Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Non-pharmacological treatments

 

 

Link to 2008 Contents page

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

Summary of the evidence by Dr Amitava Banerjee.

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) is aimed at clinicians in primary care or general medicine.  It covers:

  • Psychological interventions
  • Motor interventions
  • Nutritional supplements
  • Herbal medicine
  • Acupuncture
  • Aromatherapy
  • Creative therapy

Non-Pharmacological treatments for Dementia

The institutionalised care of patients with dementia is one of the three most expensive areas of health care in both Europe and the USA (Spijker 2008).

A meta-analysis of 13 non-pharmacological support programmes showed that such programmes can “significantly decrease the odds of institutionalisation and significantly increase the time to institutionalisation” for patients with dementia.

Effective programmes were characterized by counseling, personal assistance with problem solving, and various support strategies and services for caregivers (Spijker 2008).

Psychological interventions

There is weak evidence that behaviour problem-solving therapies and individualized, progressive, lowered stress interventions in combination with problem solving and environmental modification can be beneficial in the treatment of behavioural disturbances in dementia. However, the existing studies are small, have inadequate follow-up, and have questionable validity and reliability (Logsdon 2007).

Wandering occurs in 15–60% of people with dementia, and psychosocial interventions rather than pharmacological methods are often recommended. There is currently inadequate evidence to recommend the use of any non-pharmacological intervention to reduce wandering in dementia (Hermans 2007).

Motor interventions

Motor interventions (physiotherapy, occupational therapy, physical education, motor approach, exercise, and physical activity) can help to minimise physical and cognitive decline in dementia (Christofoletti 2007).  

Nutritional supplements

A recent systematic review found that “B vitamins and antioxidant vitamins used in the trials were unlikely to have clinically important effects on global cognitive function”, even in the patients with cognitive impairment or dementia, who had low vitamin B status. The reviewers found insufficient evidence to evaluate the effect of omega-3 fatty acids on dementia. Their review studied nutritional supplements in isolation and in combination, and concluded that the lack of benefit of supplementation is unlikely to be due to inadequate dosage (Jia 2008).

Herbal medicine

Ginkgo biloba appears to be safe in use with no excess side effects compared with placebo. A recent meta-analysis concluded that there is inconsistent and unconvincing evidence that Ginkgo has a clinically significant benefit for people with dementia or cognitive impairment (Birks 2007). A systematic review showed 2 herbs (Melissa officinalis and Salvia officinalis) and 2 formulations (Yi-Gan San and BDW) were useful for cognitive impairment in AD. M. officinalis and Yi-Gan San are also useful in agitation, for their sedative effects (Man 2008, Dos Santos 2006).

Large scale, prospective studies with adequate duration of follow-up are required to further evaluate the effectiveness these herbs fully.

Acupuncture

A Chinese meta-analysis found that acupuncture therapy is effective on dementia (Guo 2008), but a Cochrane review of its use in vascular dementia found no relevant RCTs and no evidence supporting use of acupuncture (Peng 2008). Therefore, randomised double-blind placebo controlled trials are needed before the use of acupuncture can be recommended.

Aromatherapy

A review found very poor quality data regarding the efficacy of aromatherapy in dementia and highlighted the need for prospective, randomised trials (Nguyen 2008).

Creative therapy

Creative therapies, such as art and drama, ‘aim at activating the creative potential of the patients in the sense of acceptance, orientation and coping with their illness "dementia" and at improving their quality of life’ (Schmitt 2007).

A review concluded that creative therapy led to positive effects like the improvement of interaction skills, and supported its use in order to help patients accept dementia as their illness and finally to cope with it. The reviewers recommended that new tools are required to allow the quantitative evaluation of parameters such as agility and interaction skills (Schmitt 2007).

References

  1. Birks J, Grimley EJ. Ginkgo biloba for cognitive impairment and dementia. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2007; (2):CD003120-NaN.

document.body:
1112Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Rehabilitation, practice and care standards

 

 

Link to 2008 Contents page

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

Summary of the evidence by Dr Gail Hayward

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) is aimed at clinicians in primary care or general medicine.  It covers:

  1. Improving the burden on caregivers
  2. Driving in dementia
  3. Wandering in dementia.

Interventions to improve mental health and burden in caregivers of patients with dementia

It is estimated that 63.5% of people with late onset (onset >65 years) dementia live in private households rather than care homes (Dementia UK report 2007). Therefore an important consequence of dementia is its impact upon the health of the caregivers of the patient. A quarter of caregivers are estimated to suffer from anxiety (Cooper at al 2007a).

Caring for patients with dementia has also been consistently linked with increased caregiver burden and depression (Pinquart and Sorenson 2003).

Recently the efficacy of interventions to improve both mental health and burden in caregivers have been examined. In a review of the efficacy of psychological interventions, good evidence was demonstrated for a benefit of individual behaviour management techniques lasting for 6 sessions or more on depression in caregivers (Selwood et al 2007).

Three RCTs (randomised controlled trials) demonstrated significant improvement in depression rating scales compared to controls. Interestingly, group behaviour management interventions did not result in an improvement in depression ratings, which may be because the benefit came from discussing solutions to the specific problems faced by the carer, rather than learning general principles of behaviour management.

A broader analysis of information and support interventions for caregivers, including technological interventions such as specialised computer and telephone networks and individual and group training or education programmes provides somewhat contradictory evidence to that described above.

Thompson et al (2007) found that group based psychoeducational interventions were significantly beneficial to caregivers mental health in a meta-analysis of 5 studies (-0.71 95% CI -0.95 - -0.46), but that there was no evidence for effectiveness of any other intervention, including individual interventions, on a range of physical and psychological outcomes.

However, these studies did not specifically examine behaviour management techniques but rather encompassed a wide variety of different interventions.

There is least evidence for interventions addressing anxiety in caregivers. A recent systematic review (Cooper et al 2007b) discovered only 1 RCT directly examining this. This study demonstrated a significant reduction in caregiver anxiety levels following an intervention involving relaxation and cognitive behavioural therapy.

Combined interventions, which involve both the caregiver and the care receiver in appropriate support or rehabilitation activities, have previously been suggested to be more effective for caregivers (Brodaty et al 2003). However, in a review of the effects of combined interventions, Smits et al (2007) found only a modest effect on the mental health of the caregivers, with only 2 of 7 studies showing significant improvement in depression but 3 of 4 studies showing significant improvement at some point after the intervention in general / psychosomatic and psychological complaints. Just under half of the interventions benefited both the carereceiver and caregiver in some way. The main benefit to the patient of such interventions was increased time to institutionalisation, found in 8 out of the 12 studies which examined this.

This last finding does seem to generalise to other interventions. Non-pharmacological support programmes have been shown to significantly reduce the odds of institutionalisation in patients with dementia, as demonstrated in a meta-analysis of 13 different support programmes (OR 0.66 95% CI 0.43 – 0.99) (Spijker et al (2008).

Managing dementia – updates to research into driving and wandering in dementia

Driving

A diagnosis of dementia does not automatically exclude patients from driving in the UK, although as the disease progresses the DVLA may seek information from medical records and / or driving assessment to suggest that a licence is revoked.

A recent attempt has been made to establish the extent to which patients with dementia are at greater driving risk (Man-Son-Hing et al 2007). Studies examining driver performance in road evaluations or simulations, or those which used caregiver crash reports, reveal patients with dementia to perform significantly worse than control subjects.

Interestingly, only 1 of 3 studies using state driving crash records as an outcome measure found that drivers with dementia crashed more than controls, which may be due to the poor detection of minor crashes and out-of-state accidents.

The authors found an overall increased risk of crashing of between 2 and 8 times using caregiver crash reports. They were unable to quantify the driving risk related to the degree of cognitive impairment, and further found no evidence based options for compensatory strategies to enhance the driving capabilities of persons with dementia.

Wandering

Wandering in dementia is a behaviour which can be associated with physical harm, early institutionalisation and emotional distress. It is commonly managed with physical barriers or restraints, which can pose ethical concerns, or drugs, which can produce harmful side effects.

A systematic review (Robinson et al 2007) of the literature on non-pharmacological interventions to reduce wandering revealed only exercise therapy, examined in a single RCT, to be of significant benefit. However, this paper failed to report its data fully, casting doubt on the strength of this result.

Of other interventions examined, therapeutic touch was effective at reducing pacing but not wandering, there were heterogenous results of the use of essential oils and a meta-analysis of the use of multisensory environments revealed an insignificant benefit.

1112Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Evidence on other Dementias

 

 

 

 

 

Link to 2008 Contents page

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

Summary of the evidence by Dr Amitava Banerjee

 

This Annual Evidence Update (AEU) is aimed at clinicians in primary care or general medicine. It covers:

  • Frontotemporal dementia
  • Vascular dementia

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD)

(See also: AEU 1) Diagnosis and Screening)

FTD is associated with the following behaviors: apathy-abulia; disinhibition-impulsivity; loss of insight and self-referential behavior; decreased emotion and empathy; violation of social and moral norms; changes in dietary or eating behavior; and repetitive behaviors. It is less frequently associated with anxiety and mood disorders, which may be a prodrome or risk factor, and rarely presents with delusions or hallucinations (Mendez 2007).

Studies of FTD in the context of cognitive neuropsychiatry have revealed impairment of the frontomedian network in particular, as well as the right anterior insula and medial thalamus. Therefore, FTD affects neural networks enabling self-monitoring, theory of mind capabilities, processing/evaluation of internal mental states, perception of pain and emotions, and sustaining personality and self (Peng 2008).

One systematic review revealed specific neural networks for each of the three clinically defined subtypes of frontotemporal lobar degeneration, namely frontotemporal dementia, semantic dementia, and progressive non-fluent aphasia (Schroeter 2007).

The most discriminating cognitive tests between AD and FTD were measures of orientation, memory, language, visuo-motor function and general cognitive ability.

However, given the large overlap in the test performance of persons diagnosed with AD and FTD, cognitive tests should be used with caution and in conjunction with a medical history, behavioural observations, imaging and information from relatives when making differential diagnoses of dementia (Hutchinson 2007).

Vascular dementia

Vascular dementia is caused by cerebrovascular disease. There is currently insufficient data to support the use of cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, galantamine and rivastigmine) and memantine in vascular dementia. Individual patient analyses are needed to identify subgroups of patients with vascular dementia who might benefit (Kavirajan 2007).

'Yizhi capsule' is a Chinese traditional medicine which has been used in the treatment of vascular dementia for improving cognitive function. However, a recent review found no randomised placebo-controlled trials that considered 'Yizhi capsule' for patients with vascular dementia and so could not recommend its use in vascular dementia (Wu 2007).

111-1Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Contents

   

Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia

Annual Evidence Update 2008

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

The Later Life Specialist Library’s Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update aims to provide healthcare professionals with a clear path to the most important recent evidence surrounding the five major types of dementias: Alzheimer’s; Vascular dementia; Dementia with lewy bodies; Frontotemporal dementia; and mixed dementias.

 

The Dementia AEU provides bibliographies and clinical commentary on secondary research (systematic reviews, meta analyses and guidelines) from the last 14 months for the following topics:

 

  1. Definitions, Diagnosis and screening
  2. Risk factors and aetiology
  3. Pharmacological treatments
  4. Non-pharmacological treatments
  5. Rehabilitation, practice and care standards
  6. Evidence on other Dementias.
          

You can read and download the methodology here.

Please send us your feedback here.

document.description: The Later Life Specialist Library Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008 presents the results of extensive literature searches carried out to identify guidelines, systematic reviews and meta-analyses relating to dementia.
document.body:
111-1Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Methodology

Link to the Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2008: Contents page

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page


Alzheimer’s Disease and Dementia
Annual Evidence Update 2008: Methodology

 


a. Inclusion criteria

References are included if they are identified as guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, or publication types further down the evidence hierarchy which are relevant to the subject scope and have been reviewed by the clinical lead and a team of referees.

 

b. Exclusion criteria

We excluded references about types of dementia or cognitive disorders which are not commonly found in older people, such as: Pick’s disease, Huntington’s disease, Creutzfeldt Jakob Syndrome, Kluver Bucy Syndrome, Wernicke Encephalopathy, and Korsakoff’s Syndrome.

 


c. Publication types

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses are the highest level of evidence to inform clinical practice, in line with the Centre for Evidence Based Medicine’s ‘Levels of Evidence’ document (May 2001).  Our criteria for classifying a reference as a definite systematic review was based on NLH Specialist Libraries guidance on identifying systematic reviews , in combination with the definition of a systematic review from the Glossary of Cochrane Collaboration Terms on the Cochrane Collaboration website.

 

d. Sources to search

We searched the following databases using NLH Search 2.0 Healthcare databases advanced search:

  • Cinahl
  • Embase
  • Psycinfo

We also searched PubMed, the Cochrane Library and the Later Life Specialist Library.

 


e. Search period

We searched by Publication Year 2007-2008 in the Healthcare databases advanced search, and more specifically in PubMed (01 June 2007 – 01 August 2008).

 

f. Search strategy

We based the search strategy on the Cochrane Dementia and Cognitive Improvement Group’s Medline (1966 to 2008/02) search string:

  1. ((prevent$ or delay$ or reduc$) and (dement$ or alzheimer$ or (cognit$ adj5 impair$))).ti,ab
  2. ((cognit$ or memory$ or mental$ or cerebral or "mild cognitive function" or mci or "brain activity") and (improv$ or enhanc$ or perform$ or process$)).ti,ab
  3. ((prevent$ adj5 los$) or (prevent$ adj5 deteriorat$)).ti,ab
  4. ((cognit$ adj5 declin$) or (cognit$ adj5 deficit$)).ti,ab
  5. 3 and 4
  6. 1 or 2 or 5
  7. dement$.ti,ab
  8. alzheimer$.ti,ab
  9. (lewy$ and bod$).ti,ab
  10. deliri$.ti,ab
  11. ((cognit$ or memory$ or mental$) and (declin$ or impair$ or los$ or deteriorat$)).ti,ab
  12. (chronic and cerebrovascular) .ti,ab
  13. ("organic brain disease" or "organic brain syndrome").ti,ab
  14. "supra nuclear palsy".ti,ab
  15. ("normal pressure hydrocephalus" and shunt$).ti,ab
  16. "benign senescent forgetfulness".ti,ab
  17. (cerebr$ and deteriorat$).ti,ab
  18. (cerebr$ and insufficien$).ti,ab
  19. (confusion$ or confused) .ti,ab
  20. binswanger$.ti,ab
  21. "alzheimer disease"/
  22. exp "dementia vascular"/
  23. "lewy body disease"/
  24. "delirium"/
  25. 7 or 8 or 9 or 10 or 11 or 12 or 13 or 14 or 15 or 16 or 17 or 18 or 19 or 20 or 21 or 22 or 23 or 24
  26. 6 or 25
  27. hiv$.ti,ab
  28. 26 not 27
  29. aids.ti,ab
  30. 28 not 29
  31. stroke.ti,ab
  32. 30 not 31
  33. diabet$.ti,ab
  34. 32 not 33
  35. heart.ti,ab
  36. 34 not 35
  37. epilep$.ti,ab
  38. 36 not 37
  39. schizophre$.ti,ab
  40. 38 not 39
  41. child$.ti,ab
  42. 40 not 41
  43. systematic.ti.ab.
  44. 42 and 43
  45. 44 [Limit to: Publication Year 2007-2008]

 

g. Sifting and selection

All citations found in the searches were sifted by the Later Life Specialist Library information scientist. The references were then sent to two reviewers, Drs Amitava Banerjee and Gail Hayward, who summarised the evidence in six commentaries on the following subjects:

  1. Definitions, Diagnosis and screening
  2. Risk factors and aetiology
  3. Pharmacological treatments
  4. Non-pharmacological treatments
  5. Rehabilitation, practice and care standards
  6. Evidence on other Dementias.

 


h. Results

 
We also included two Cochrane systematic reviews which were published after the search period:

  1. Isaac MGEKN, Quinn R, Tabet N. Vitamin E for Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD002854. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD002854.pub2.
  2. Forbes D, Forbes S, Morgan DG, Markle-Reid M, Wood J, Culum I. Physical activity programs for persons with dementia. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD006489. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD006489.pub2.

111-1Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009: Contents

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

NHS Evidence - later life's Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009 aims to provide healthcare professionals with a clear path to the most important recent evidence surrounding the five major types of dementia: Alzheimer’s; Vascular dementia; Dementia with Lewy bodies; Frontotemporal dementia; and Mixed dementias.

The Dementia AEU provides bibliographies on secondary research (systematic reviews, meta analyses and guidelines) from the last 18 months for the following topics:

  1. Definitions, Diagnosis and Screening
  2. Risk Factors and Aetiology
  3. Pharmacological Treatments
  4. Non-Pharmacological Treatments
  5. Rehabilitation, Practice and Care Standards
  6. Evidence on Other Dementias

 

Our bibliographies are presented in three sections:

Systematic reviews
Systematic reviews that have been published or updated in the last year.  Systematic reviews aim to find, assess and summarise all of the research that has been conducted on a specific topic.  We identify systematic reviews by checking the abstract for the key sections of a systematic review:  inclusion criteria, search strategy, study selection and evaluation, data extraction and statistical analysis.

Other reviews
This sub-section contains relevant reviews whose abstracts do not contain all of the key sections of a systematic review.  As such, some of these documents will be genuine systematic reviews, whilst others will be less rigorous overviews of the topic.  You should check the methods section to see if these reviews made sufficient efforts to find and include all of the relevant evidence.

Other important evidence
We use this category as a “catch-all” for studies, such as critical appraisals of individual trials, that are relevant but do not fit into either of the above two categories.

 

Recent 2008-2009 Guidelines

  1. Department of Health. Living well with dementia: a National Dementia Strategy. 2009.
  2. Department of Health. Living well with dementia: the National Dementia Strategy joint commissioning framework for dementia. 2009.
  3. Department of Health. Living well with dementia: a National Dementia Strategy Implementation Plan. 2009.
  4. Department of Health. Guidance on nominating a consultee for research involving adults who lack capacity to consent. 2008
  5. Royal College of Physicians. Long-term neurological conditions: management at the interface between neurology, rehabilitation and pallative care. 2008.

 Other Important Guidelines

  1. NICE. Alzheimer's disease - drug treatments. 2007.
  2. NICE. Commissioning Guides: Memory assessment service for the early identification and care of people with dementia. 2007.
  3. NICE. Dementia: supporting people with dementia and their carers in health and social care. 2006.
  4. NICE. Donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine (review) and memantine for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. 2007.
  5. Royal College of Psychiatrists. Copying clinical letters to patients: guidelines for old age psychiatrists. 2004.
  6. Royal College of Psychiatrists. Forgetful but not forgotten: assessment and aspects of treatment of people with dementia by a specialist old age psychiatry service. 2005.
  7. Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists. Position Paper: speech and language therapy provision for people with dementia. 2005.
  8. SIGN. Management of patients with dementia: a national clinical guideline. 2006.

International Guidelines

  1. American College of Physicians. Current pharmacological treatment of dementia: a clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians and the American Academy of Family Physicians. 2008.

 

You can read and download the following documents below:

  • Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009 Methodology PDF
  • Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009 Publicity Poster PDF
  • Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009 Press Release PDF

111-1Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009: Rehabilitation, Practice and Care Standards

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

Back to Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009 Contents Page

 

This section contains important new evidence about all aspects of caring for people with dementia or Alzheimer’s Disease.

The scope includes feeding, predictors of nursing home admissions, risk factors for falls in people with dementia, telehealth and other new technologies, quality of life research

There is a substantial amount of evidence about supporting caregivers, including providing information, respite care, telehealth and psychological interventions.

The evidence also encompasses broader social issues, such as housing, and research about different settings of care:  acute care, the role of general practitioners and palliative care.

111-1Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009: Risk Factors and Aetiology

Link to 2010 Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update Contents Page

Back to Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2009 Contents Page

 

This section contains material about risk factors for dementia and cognitive decline.  The evidence explores links with cardiovascular risk factors such as blood pressure, glucose intolerance, interactions with other drug treatments and links with obesity, smoking and alcohol use.  Prognostic reviews, reporting the likely progression of disease, are also included.
 
We also include material about prevention, such as Vitamin B6 supplementation, statins and blood pressure lowering.

document.body:
111-1Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Annual Evidence Update 2010: Contents

NHS Evidence - later life's Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia AEU 2010 aims to provide healthcare professionals with a clear path to the most important recent evidence surrounding the five major types of dementia: Alzheimer’s; Vascular dementia; Dementia with Lewy bodies; Frontotemporal dementia; and Mixed dementias.

The Dementia AEU provides bibliographies on secondary research (systematic reviews, meta analyses and guidelines) from the last 18 months for the following topics:

  1. Definitions, Diagnosis, Screening and Prevention
  2. Risk Factors and Aetiology
  3. Pharmacological Treatments
  4. Non-Pharmocological Treatments
  5. Models of Dementia Care
  6. Evidence on Other Dementias

 

Recent Guidelines (2009 - 2010):

  1. Department of Health. End of Life Care Strategy: Second Annual Report. 2010.
  2. NICE. Quality standard for dementia. 2010.
  3. NICE. Delirium: diagnosis, prevention and management. 2010.
  4. Department of Health. Improving care and saving money: learning the lessons on prevention and early intervention for older people. 2010.
  5. Royal College of Psychiatrists. Dementia and people with learning disabilities. 2009
  6. Department of Health. Living well with dementia: a National Dementia Strategy. 2009.
  7. Department of Health. Living well with dementia: the National Dementia Strategy joint commissioning framework for dementia. 2009.
  8. Department of Health. Living well with dementia: a National Dementia Strategy Implementation Plan. 2009.
  9. Royal College of Physicians. Long-term neurological conditions: management at the interface between neurology, rehabilitation and pallative care. 2008.

Other important Guidelines & Publications:

  1. College of Optometrists. Code of ethics and guidelines for professional conduct C4: examining a patient with dementia. 2010.
  2. General Medical Council. Treatment and care towards the end of life: good practice in decision making. 2010.
  3. Department of Health. Report on the prescribing of anti-psychotic drugs to people with dementia. 2009
  4. NICE. Donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine (review) and memantine for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. 2009.
  5. Alzheimer's Society. Dementia: What every commissioner needs to know. 2009
  6. NHS End of Life Care. Commissioning End of Life Care. 2009.
  7. NICE. Commissioning Guide: Memory assessment service for the early identification and care of people with dementia. 2007.
  8. NICE. Alzheimer's disease - drug treatments. 2007.
  9. NICE. Dementia: supporting people with dementia and their carers in health and social care. 2006.
  10. SIGN. Management of patients with dementia: a national clinical guideline. 2006.
  11. Royal College of Psychiatrists. Forgetful but not forgotten: assessment and aspects of treatment of people with dementia by a specialist old age psychiatry service. 2005.
  12. Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists. Position Paper: speech and language therapy provision for people with dementia. 2005.

Other important publications:

  1. House of Commons Public Accounts Committee. Improving dementia services  in England - an interim report: Nineteenth report of session 2009-2010. 2010.

International Guidelines:

  1. American College of Physicians. Current pharmacological treatment of dementia: a clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians and the American Academy of Family Physicians. 2008.

The category of definitions contains evidence relating to how we define and understand dementia. This includes: reviews of experimental models, practitioner roles, prevalence studies and social, personal and economic impact of dementia.

We have grouped the evidence into the following subtopics:

  • Definitions

document.name: <![CDATA[ Later Life]]>
document.title: An Inherited Variable Poly-T Repeat Genotype in TOMM40 in Alzheimer Disease
document.body: <![CDATA[ I coauthored a recently published research article describing a variable length, poly-T polymorphism in the TOMM40 gene, adjacent to apolipoprotein E (APOE) on chromosome 19, that accounts for the age at onset distribution for a complex disease, late-onset Alzheimer disease. These new data explain the mean age at disease onset for patients with the APOE4/4 genotype and differentiate 2 forms of TOMM40 poly-T polymorphisms linked to APOE, with each form associated with a different age at disease onset distribution. When linked to APOE3 (encoding the {varepsilon}3 isoform of APOE), the longer TOMM40 poly-T repeats (19-39 nucleotides) at the rs10524523 (hereafter, 523) locus are associated with earlier age at onset and the shorter TOMM40 523 alleles (11-16 nucleotides) are associated with later age at onset. The data suggest that the poly-T alleles are codominant, with the age at onset phenotype determined by the 2 inherited 523 alleles, but with variable expressivity. Additional data will further refine the relationship between the length of the poly-T alleles and age at disease onset and determine if the relationship is linear.]]>

document.title: An in-home preventive assessment program for independent older adults: a randomized controlled trial
document.publisher: Journal of the American Geriatrics Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ LATER LIFE,HEART DISEASE,CANCER,SCREENING,SCREENING AND SURVEILLANCE,OSTEOPOROSIS,CARDIOVASCULAR RISK,MENTAL HEALTH,RISK OF FALLS,HEARING,THYROID DISEASE,DIABETES,EYESIGHT]]>
document.body:
Objectives:

To evaluate the effectiveness of in-home geriatric assessments as a means of providing preventive health care and improving health and functional status of community-living elderly veterans.  

Conclusions:

A brief geriatric screening assessment performed in the home can detect unrecognized and treatable problems, even among relatively healthy older adults. The use of trained volunteers is a feasible strategy for providing health education and follow-up contacts. These results support the concept that preventive gerontological approaches can help maintain important aspects of health and function.

]]>

document.title: Analysis of trials evaluating combinations of acetylsalicylic acid and dipyridamole in the secondary prevention of stroke
document.body:
This systematic review has been appraised by the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination (CRD).

CRD summary:

" Differences in the aspirin and dipyridamole doses and the methodology used may explain why the addition of dipyridamole to aspirin has only recently been demonstrated to provide benefit in the secondary prevention of stroke. Further studies are needed to confirm the long-term benefit.

The authors' conclusions are supported by the review but are rather too general given the available data".

]]>

document.title: Annual assessment of patients aged 75 years and over: general practitioners' and practice nurses' views and experiences
document.body:
Objectives:

A study was undertaken to collect details of practice organization of these assessments, general practitioners' and practice nurses' experience of assessments, and their views of the value of such assessments.

Conclusions:

The findings suggest that the experiences of the first two years of this activity had convinced some general practitioners that routine assessment of elderly patients is worthwhile. However the increased demand for other services must obviously be met by an increase in resources if the effectiveness of these assessments is not to be undermined.

]]>

document.body:
Objectives:

To describe the characteristics of elderly people who declined the offer of an annual home visit.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Later Life]]>
document.title: Antithrombotic therapy to prevent stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation: a meta-analysis
document.body:
This meta analysis has been reviewed by Bandolier:

"This is a review written by people involved in some of the main trials in this area, and with a view to examining benefit and harm. The reviews will also be available separately on the Cochrane Library in early 2000.

The authors modelled the effects of treatment - the benefit in terms of reductions in all-cause strokes, and the harm in terms of major extracranial bleeds. The effects based on cohorts of 1000 patients over one year, at various baseline risk of stroke and for primary and secondary prevention are shown in Table 2 . Benefit outweighs harm.

Given that atrial fibrillation is often aggressively treated in primary care, and is relatively common (three million warfarin prescriptions in primary care in England in 1998), this conclusion is comforting. The review did not deal with people with structural heart disease, in whom the risk of stroke may be higher. It is a worthwhile read".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Later Life]]>
document.title: Apathy symptom profile and behavioural associations in frontotemporal dementia vs dementia of Alzheimer type
document.body:
Background:
Apathy is a common and significant problem in patients with dementia, regardless of its cause. Observations about frontosubcortical circuit syndromes indicate that apathy may have affective, behavioral, or cognitive manifestations.

Objectives:
To explore whether the apathy manifested in frontotemporal dementia (FTD), with its predominantly anterior brain neuropathologic features, differs from the apathy in dementia of Alzheimer type (DAT), with its predominantly hippocampal- and temporoparietal-based neuropathologic features, and to determine whether other behavioral disturbances reported in frontosubcortical circuit syndromes correlate with apathy.

Design:
Analyses included individual items within Neuropsychiatric Inventory subscale items. Items of the apathy/indifference subscale were designated by consensus as affective (lacking in emotions), behavioral (inactive, chores abandoned), or cognitive (no interest in the activities of others). Proportions of correlated nonapathy Neuropsychiatric Inventory items were calculated.

Setting:
Several neurology specialty clinics contributed to our data set.

Participants:
A total of 92 participants with FTD and 457 with DAT.

Main Outcome Measures:
The Neuropsychiatric Inventory was analyzed.

Results:
Apathy was more prevalent in patients with FTD than in those with DAT, but when present, the specific apathy symptoms associated with both types of dementia were rarely restricted to 1 of the 3 domains of apathy. Dysphoria concurrent with apathy was unique to the DAT group and negatively correlated in the FTD group. Participants with affective apathy more frequently copresented with an orbital frontosubcortical syndrome in FTD (impulsivity and compulsions). Affective apathy also copresented with uncooperative agitation, anger, and physical agitation in both types of dementia.

Conclusions:
Apathy is common in patients with FTD and DAT, although it is more common in those with FTD. When present, it usually involves changes in affect, behavior, and cognition. It is associated with behaviors that have previously been shown to affect patient safety, independence, and quality of life.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Later Life]]>
document.title: Assessment of hearing loss in elderly people: the feasibility of a nurse administered screening test
document.body:
Summary

This paper examines the findings and implications of an exploratory study which was designed to determine the feasibility of a nurse administered hearing screen test for elderly patients. Theoretical and practical considerations which influenced the design of the hearing assessment test (HAT) and the method of the study are discussed. A sample of 27 elderly hospital inpatients, with a mean age of 81 years, participated in the study. The results of the new HAT were validated by comparison with audiometric assessment results. Analysis using the Generalized Linear Model showed a significant (P less than or equal to 0.01) relationship between the total HAT score and the audiometric measures, with the exception of the audiometric classification of hearing loss which was significant at P less than or equal to 0.05. The results demonstrate that the HAT is a potentially useful tool for nurses to use, but that refinement of the scale and further validity and reliability testing is required before it can be adopted as part of the nursing assessment of elderly people.

]]>

document.title: Assessment of patients aged over 75 in general practice
document.body:
Objectives:

To evaluate the assessment scheme for people aged 75, to establish doctors' and nurses' views on the value of the assessment scheme, and to seek patients' opinions on elderly assessments.

Conclusions:

Doctors see no merit in the scheme; most undertake assessments opportunistically and pick up few new problems. Nurses who see it as important require further training to fit them to do home visits confidently. Patients who were assessed found it worth while. The case for developing a specialist community nurse for elderly people should be investigated.

]]>

Objectives  To determine whether decline in cognitive function was greater among older individuals who experienced acute care or critical illness hospitalizations relative to those not hospitalized and to determine whether the risk for incident dementia differed by these exposures.

The authors of the paper discuss possible mechanisms in great detail, and it is an interesting read.

document.body:
This cohort study has been reviewed by Bandolier:

Clinical bottom line:

"Evidence from randomised trials shows a small increased risk of stroke in patients with dementia and agitation treated with atypical antipsychotics risperidone and olanzapine, but based on a small number of events. A large observational study failed to find any increased risk, and probably limits the size of the effect to no more than two extra strokes per 1000 person years of treatment".
